Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge correctly apply the residency requirement under section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 691 days over four years
Applicant worked internationally during the period
Judge made errors in employment dates and passport stamp interpretations
Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable due to factual errors and misapplication of law
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; case remanded to another Citizenship Judge for reassessment
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge misapplied facts and legal test
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to conduct 'centralized mode of existence' comparison between Canada and other countries
Legal_Standard: 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada over four years
Assessment_Factor: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Procedural_Issue: Errors in factual findings and application of legal tests by the Citizenship Judge
Application_Basis: Physical presence and residential ties to Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Comparative residential connections to Canada vs. other countries
Governing_Rule: Re Koo's centralized mode of existence test
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to incorrect legal application
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged denial of citizenship based on alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Errors in interpreting passport stamps and employment evidence
Residency_Compliance: Not met according to original decision; subject to re-evaluation
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient and inaccurately assessed in initial decision
Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly apply the centralized mode of existence test
Unreasonable conclusion based on incorrect facts
